items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College is pleased to partner with College of the Canyons to develop an institutional effectiveness and technical assistance program to benefit all California Community Colleges and students.  
	 
The Institutional Effectiveness Partnership Initiative (IEPI) is a collaborative effort to help advance the institutional effectiveness of California Community Colleges.  Most importantly, IEPI will enhance the system’s ability to effectively serve students. It is jointly administered by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office and College of the Canyons. Major components of the initiative include development of the statewide indicators per SB 852 and SB 860, making Technical Assistance Teams (now called Partnership Resource Teams) and implementation grants available to colleges interested in receiving assistance, and providing professional development opportunities.
	 
Foothill College will facilitate logistics of the Technical Assistance Teams and coordinate workshops offered in the northern part of the state.  Each year Foothill College will develop a professional development calendar in coordination with College of the Canyons staff.   In partnership with College of the Canyons, Foothill College will be responsible for coordinating visiting team logistics for institutions in Northern California (individual team member reimbursements will be handled by College of the Canyons).
	 
The Foothill College Vice President of Instruction serves on the Advisory Committee and the Associate Vice President of Instruction serves on the Executive Committee of the grant.  We anticipate hiring individual(s) to support the grant activities in summer 2015.
	 
This is a five year contract totaling $883,333 to be invoiced monthly.
	 
Submitted by:
 Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
 Kimberlee Messina, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
At the March 3, 2014, meeting, the trustees approved a resolution in support of California community colleges offering baccalaureate degrees in applied and technical fields. On March 16, 2015, the Board of Governors approved Foothill Collegeâs application for a Baccalaureate of Science in Dental Hygiene.  On March 18, the Foothill College Planning and Resource Council (PaRC) endorsed (first read) the Substantive Change Proposal to the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior College's (ACCJC) for the new program.
	 
The attached Substantive Change Proposal follows ACCJCâs guidelines for Bachelor Degrees for community colleges and outlines the rationale and curriculum for the new program.  The proposal will be reviewed at the May 7, 2015, ACCJC Substantive Change Committee meeting.
	 
The new program will begin in fall 2016 and includes 86 General Education quarter units, spread across the lower and upper division, and 100 Dental Hygiene major quarter units, totaling 186 quarter units, or 124 semester units.
	 
The new program will replace the existing Associates in Science program and will use existing faculty, learning, and student support resources.  Students will continue to take the same National Dental Hygiene Board examination.
	 
Planning is also underway that would allow existing Dental Hygiene Associate Degree holders to complete bachelor level requirements.   
	 
Submitted by:
 Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
 Kimberlee Messina, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: The Foothill College administration recommends approval of the Substantive Change Proposal for a Baccalaureate Degree in Dental Hygiene.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Celebrity Forum Speaker Series has been a part of Foothill College for 47 years. The series is an important community event and draws thousands of people each year to Flint Center. From its founding in 1968, the series has been completely self-supporting and has never used District or college funds for its operation, being financed solely through ticket sales. The series has always been a financial success and has contributed valuable discretionary dollars to Foothill College.
	 
The Foothill College Celebrity Forum has secured January 20, 21, 22, 2016 for lectures by Mark Russell through his representative at Mallark Productions, LLC. The agreed upon fees for the three appearances is $80,000. This does not include travel fees. This amount will be due before his actual appearances in January.
	 
This item is being submitted to the board for contract approval.
	 
Submitted by:
 Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
 Bernata Slater, Dick Henning
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill-De Anza Community College District (CCD) of behalf of Foothill College is requesting to enter into a contract with Cabrillo Community College District. Cabrillo CCD has been designated as the fiscal agent for the 28-college Bay region for the administration of the Career Technical Education (CTE) Enhancement Fund (Grant No. 14-187-007) from the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office. The amount of the CTE Enhancement Fund grant for Foothill College is $345,433. The purpose of this grant is to develop, enhance, retool and expand quality CTE offerings and enhance the college’s capacity to respond to regional labor market needs. Foothill College’s CTE Enhancement Fund allocation will be used to acquire instructional equipment, develop new curriculum, and support outreach to underrepresented populations. CTE Enhancement Fund grant monies will be used to improve Foothill CTE programs that are aligned with designated Priority Industry Sectors: Veterinary Technology, Allied Health, Computer Science, Engineering, and Business.
	 
Submitted by:
 Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
 John Mummert, Kevin McElroy

Background and Analysis:
	 
The California Community College Trustees (CCCT) Board of Directors is conducting an election between March 10 and April 25 to fill seven vacancies for three-year terms on the CCCT Board. The Board of Trustees, as a body, is entitled to submit one vote for each of the seven vacancies.  Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The student trustees may cast advisory votes to be used to resolve any ties that result in more than seven candidates being selected.
	 
A list of the ten candidates who have been nominated, candidate nomination forms, and statements of candidacy are attached. 
	 
The results of the election will be announced at the Community College League of California Trustees Conference, which is being held May 1-3 in Monterey.

Background and Analysis:
	 
In keeping with the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure Service templates, the Chancellor's Advisory Council approved moving the language of the district's instructional material fees board policy (BP) into new administrative procedure (AP) 5031 Instructional Materials Fees. The language incorporated into the procedure was also updated to reflect changes in the laws and regulations governing such fees.
	 
Since the district's authority to charge fees for instructional materials is set forth in the revision to the fees policy (BP 5030), which is included separately on this agenda, and the new administrative procedure includes the modified language of the district's current instructional materials fees policy, retirement of BP 5020 Instructional and Other Materials and Use Fees is recommended.
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved AP 5031 Instructional Materials Fees on March 20, 2015. The governing board will be asked to approve retirement of BP 5020 Instructional and Other Material and Use Fees at the May 4, 2015, meeting.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Voting members of the Faculty Association have ratified the tentative agreement on the topic of 2014-2015 compensation. The Board is hereby requested to approve the 2014-2015 compensation settlement reached between the Foothill-De Anza Community College District and the Faculty Association for 2014-2015. 
	 
The 2014-15 compensation settlement includes the following:
	 
Effective July 1, 2014:
A salary adjustment of 2.50% (equivalent to the State-provided .85% COLA plus 1.65%) on all salary schedules, Appendices A, B, B.1, C, D, D.1, E, and G. 
Effective July 1, 2015:
Creation of a new Appendix C.1 with compensation at the current 77.5% of Appendix A, which shall apply to full-time faculty overload assignments. Appendix C.1 shall also apply to Contract Education covered under Article 37 of the Agreement.
One step added to the part-time faculty salary schedules B.1, C, C.1 (new), D, E, and G, for a total of 7 steps.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
An Election was held in the Foothill-De Anza Community College District (the “District”) on June 6, 2006 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum amount of $490,800,000 (the “2006 Authorization”).  The District has previously issued bonds under the 2006 Authorization, including (i) $149,995,250.35 of its Election of 2006 General Obligation Bonds, Series A (the “2006 Series A Bonds”), and (ii) $99,996,686.15 of its Election of 2006 General Obligation Bonds, Series B (the “2006 Series B Bonds,” and together with the 2006 Series A Bonds, the “Prior Bonds”). In August 2014, the District refunded a portion of the Prior Bonds.
	 
The District now desires to refinance portions of the callable Prior Bonds, in particular, the current interest bonds maturing in 2031, through the issuance of general obligation refunding bonds in an aggregate principal amount of not-to-exceed $110,000,000.  All the benefits of refunding must be given to the local taxpayers; the District will not receive any money from the transaction.  In addition, the final maturity of the Refunding Bonds will not exceed the final maturity date of the Prior Bonds.
 
(a)        Bond Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of general obligation refunding bonds (the “Refunding Bonds”), in one or more series of federally taxable and federally tax-exempt bonds.  The resolution specifies the basic terms, parameters and forms of the Bonds, and approves the forms of Purchase Contract, Escrow Agreement and Preliminary Official Statement described below.  The Bonds are only authorized to be issued as current interest bonds.  Capital appreciation bonds are not authorized.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate principal amount of the Refunding Bonds issued ($110,000,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriting discount (1.0%) with respect to the Refunding Bonds, and authorizes the Refunding Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC (the “Underwriter”).
 
(b)        Form of Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, the Underwriter will agree to buy the Refunding Bonds from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
(c)        Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (“POS”) is the offering document describing the Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to among other things (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Bonds (the tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
(d)        Form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate.  The form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate can be found in APPENDIX C to the POS.  Effective July 3, 1995, all underwriters of municipal bonds, are obligated to procure from a bond issuer a covenant that such public agency will annually file “material financial information and operating data with respect to the District” through the web-based Electronic Municipal Market Access (“EMMA”) system maintained by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (which is the federal agency that regulates “broker-dealers,” including investment bank firms that underwrite municipal obligation issuances).  This requirement is expected to be satisfied by the filing of the District’s audited financial statements and other operating information about the District, in the same manner the District has filed in connection with prior bond issuances.  The purpose of the law is to provide investors in the Refunding Bonds with current information regarding the District.  Similar laws have governed the corporate debt market for many years.
	 
 (e)       Escrow Agreement.  Pursuant to the Escrow Agreement, proceeds from the sale of the Refunding Bonds in an amount sufficient to redeem the outstanding Prior Bonds will be deposited in an escrow fund (the “Escrow Fund”) held by U.S. Bank National Association (acting as “Escrow Agent”).  The monies in the Escrow Fund will be used by the Escrow Agent to refund portions of the 2006 Series A Bonds and 2006 Series B Bonds on August 1, 2017.  As a result of the deposit and application of funds so provided in the Escrow Agreement, the Prior Bonds will be defeased and the obligation of Santa Clara County to levy ad valorem taxes for payment of the Prior Bonds will cease.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
	 
There is no fiscal impact to the General Fund resulting from the issuance of the Bonds. 
	 
RECOMMENDATION
	 
Staff recommends approval of Resolution # 2015-07, RESOLUTION AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE OF THE FOOTHILL-DE ANZA COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT (SANTA CLARA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA) 2015 GENERAL OBLIGATION REFUNDING BONDS.
	 
See attached Executive Summary for more detail.
	 
         Vice Chancellor of Business Services, Kevin McElroy recommends that the Board:
	 
           1.  Approve Resolution No. 2015-07 authorizing Issuance of 2015 General Obligation Refunding Bonds
	 
           2.  Approve the form of the Preliminary Official Statement
	 
           3.  Approve the form of the Purchase Contract and;
	 
           4.  Approve the form of the Escrow Agreement.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
 Joni Hayes, Director, Budget Operations, x6261

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Public safety agencies in Santa Clara County have begun to utilize a new interoperable radio system to improve communications during emergency situations. The initiative was born out of communications deficiencies identified during the 9/11 attacks. An interoperable radio system where all public safety agencies could share critical information was made a national priority. Both Santa Clara and Sunnyvale departments have moved to the new system this past year and more agencies will migrate as additional infrastructure comes on line.  It is anticipated that the District will join the new system when coverage becomes available to both campuses.
	 
The District's Police Department is part of the County Mutual Aid Master Plan and can be called upon to respond to any major emergency. The ability to communicate with our mutual aid partners is essential. Additionally, the new Foothill Education Center is scheduled to open in the Fall of 2016 and the District's officers will need to communicate with Sunnyvale DPS in emergency situations.
	 
In response to requests from the cities of Santa Clara and Sunnyvale to initiate implementation of the Silicon Valley Regional Communications System (SVRCS), the Silicon Valley Regional Interoperability Authority (SVRIA) undertook a vendor solicitation and selection process. A Request for Proposal (RFP) was prepared and a twelve member RFP team was established, representing seven cities, the county, and SVRIA. 
	 
The District's existing mobile and portable radios are eleven years old and at the end of their life cycle. The radios are no longer supported by the manufacturer and cannot be repaired. Because the estimated cost to replace the radios will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”.  The agreement SVRIA Contract is available and it includes the items required by the District. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the County of Santa Clara contract for the same goods and services. The contract establishes discounts for police radios and related equipment.
	 
The estimated amount is $120,000 to be funded by General Fund, Central Services Safety and Security.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Kevin McElroy, Ron Levine, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for police radio and related equipment in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and SVRIA Contract.

Background and Analysis: 
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill and De Anza College.  
	 
De Anza Budget Transfer #48 includes the following actions:
Transfer $100,000 from District Project 403, Data Center “C” to Project 202, L-7 to add funds to the project. 
Transfer $2,500,000 from District Project 403, Data Center “C” to New De Anza Project 275, L-7 Phase II to create New 275 Project Budget. New 275 Project, L-7 Phase II is initiated. Description: Upgrade the existing room located at L-7 to provide back up power, new UPS, upgrade the fire suppression system, upgrade the fire alarm system, abatement of hazardous materials, provide required code compliant raised floor, distribute interior data and electrical, provide updates to the electrical system as needed.  
Note that the current budget for Project 251 (251C), Install Photovoltaics will have an additional funding sources of $48,327.50 due to PG&E Rebates (Checks 51,54-56 Series 1 and Checks 33-35 Series 2) not shown here.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On Nov. 3, 2014, the Board authorized the use of the Lease-Leaseback contractor selection process for the L-7 Renovation project at De Anza College in accordance with Education Code 81335.
	 
On February 9, 2015, the Board authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to Swinerton Builders based upon the recommendation of the L-7 Renovation project contractor selection committee.  
	 
The Preconstruction Services Agreement required Swinerton Builders to prequalify subcontractors, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, develop an actual Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) and develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule. The GMP was established based upon the DSA-approved set of drawings and specifications. 
	 
Swinerton Builders’ GMP for this project is $2,734,249.  The scope of work includes renovating the L-7 exterior façade; renovating the classrooms interiors; upgrading power and HVAC to the building; re-roofing the flat and tile roofs with new flashings, stucco, and performance coatings; new interior and exterior painting; fire alarm upgrades; lighting upgrades, replacing indicated doors; infilling specific windows; new chair rails or re-painting of chair rails, new IDF room with data backbone, accessibility upgrades at exterior entrances, and miscellaneous interior upgrades as shown on the Contract Documents. The L-7 Renovation project is funded by Measure C.
	 
District Staff recommends that the Board of Trustees award the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements to Swinerton Builders to construct the project based upon DSA-approved construction documents for an amount not-to-exceed the GMP. Under the two agreements, the District will lease District-owned land to Swinerton Builders, and Swinerton Builders will agree to construct the Project pursuant to the District’s Construction Provisions and Swinerton Builders’ responses to RFQ/RFP 1678-202.  The District will receive incremental title to the constructed property in accordance with payments made.  The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the Project, at which time the leases will be terminated. 
	 
Upon execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease, Swinerton Builders will be given access to and control of the site to commence work. Substantial Completion of the work will be achieved by September 1, 2015.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Steven Kitchen, Tom Armstrong, Roseanne Sciacchitano, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will require the Contractor to resurface the entire Foothill College Loop Road.  The Contractor will also (1) provide new traffic control sensors, crosswalk lighting, pavement striping, and reflectors, (2) install new guardrails and, (3) provide drainage improvements at the north end of campus.  The Contractor is required to maintain vehicular access around the loop road at all times during the course of work and the project will be completed prior to the start of Fall Quarter 2015. Pavement Engineering, Inc. prepared the bid documents for the work.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on February 3 and February 10, 2015. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post-Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on March 17, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Four (4) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
	 
BID RESULTS

Pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20103.8(C), the bid specifications state that the lowest responsive, responsible bid shall be determined as the lowest total of the bid prices on the base contract and those additive items that when taken in order from a specifically identified list of those items in the bid form and added to the base contract are less than or equal to the funding amount publicly disclosed by the District. The District disclosed a funding amount of $837,000; Measure C will fund the project.   Four bid alternates were identified and prioritized as to importance of work.  Alternate #3 would improve the inside lane of the loop road, Alternate #4 would improve the outside lane of the loop road, Alternate #2 would slurry seal the entrance and exit of the campus and Alternate #1 would improve the theater road. 
	 
The apparent low bidder is Granite Rock Company with an aggregate bid amount of $813,790 for the Base Bid, plus Alternates #3, 4, and 2. Alternate #1 in the amount of $48,290 will not be accepted at this time; however, if the campus identifies additional funds for such work, then the bid specifications provide that the alternate can be accepted at a later date at the same cost provided in the bid proposal.
	 
Granite Rock has successfully completed roadway projects for Cabrillo College, County of Santa Clara, City of Mt. View, City of Redwood City, and City of Santa Cruz.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project consist of the demolition of two (2) existing storage buildings, site work and preparation for two (2) new buildings including electrical utilities, and the procurement and installation of two (2) new DSA-approved buildings to be used for athletic equipment and material supply storage. Scope includes building demolition, electrical utility installation, grading and preparation of the building pads, minor grading and asphalt paving at the entries, concrete perimeter foundations, and the placement and completion of the two (2) new buildings.
	 
Verde Designs prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1712-206 was legally advertised to contractors February 4, 2015 and February 11, 2015.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on Feb 18, 2015, and a total of thirteen (13) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on March 11, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office.  Seven (7) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
TOTAL BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
Swenson & Associates
$309,500
S&H Construction. Inc. 
$320,000
CRW Industries, Inc. 
$323,947
Calstate Construction, Inc.
$329,555
Rodan Builders, Inc.  
$358,000
R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors
$372,960
Guerra Construction Group 
$584,100
	 
	 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Swenson & Associates (Swenson).  Swenson acknowledge Amendment #1 on the bid proposal form however, they did not initial the acknowledgment.  When requested, Swenson immediately submitted a letter to purchasing confirming Amendment 1 was incorporated in its bid proposal amount.  Purchasing Services consulted with District’s legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret, regarding the missing initials.  It is his opinion that the failure of Swenson to initial the bid form, but a later curing of that shortly thereafter by Swenson, is a minor irregularity that can be waived by the District.  
	 
Furthermore, Swenson’s listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
Swenson & Associates successfully completed Project 226C, L Quad Interior/Exterior Finishes and Project #214, Corporation Yard Renovation at De Anza College.  
	 
The bid price of $309,500 submitted by Swenson & Associates is within the construction estimate of $340,000 and it is within the overall project budget of $437,000.  This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, X6166

Steve Kitchen, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez

NO
